prelude.value: The numbers used are not without their own shortcomings (you can read more about them in the methodology section), but they are still some of the most reliable data we have on the LGBT community.

stepOne.value: New York City’s Pride march route snakes its way through the city’s historic gayborhood in the West Village, running right by the Stonewall Inn on Christopher Street, the site of the 1969 riots that helped launch the gay rights movement.

stepTwo.value: The city’s gay bars are clustered on the west side of Manhattan in the West Village, Chelsea and upper Hell’s Kitchen.

stepThree.value: So it’s no surprise that when combined with data on where same-sex couples live these same areas are also highlighted. But there are also darker areas that stretch out into Brooklyn. Let’s look at how this differs by gender:

stepFour.value: The area with the highest concentration of male same-sex couples mirrors the overall gayborhood index. Men congregate where the majority of the bars are.

stepFive.value: When we look at female same-sex couples, we see a different pattern. Although there is some overlap with male couples up the west side of Manhattan, female same-sex couples are overall less concentrated with the strongest cluster appearing in Park Slope, Brookyn.

details2.value: Gayborhoods, like any neighborhoods, are living things — they adapt, evolve and get redefined by the people that live and congregate in them.

In his book “There Goes the Gayborhood?” Amin Ghaziani, Associate Professor of Sociology and Canada Research Chair in Sexuality and Urban Studies at the University of British Columbia, looks at LGBT spaces over three broad time periods in sexual history:

periods2.periodDesc: Gayborhoods as we know them today didn’t exist in this pre-World War II period. The LGBT community was underground and secretive because it wasn’t widely socially acceptable. After WWII as people began to flee the cities for the suburbs, LGBT communities moved into the disinvested cities to build their own enclaves.

This era of “We’re here, we’re queer!” lasted from WWII to about 1997. The LGBT community began to cluster in areas like New York’s West Village and San Francisco Castro, and built gayborhoods on civil rights and activism.
The current post-gay era is heavily influenced by more widespread acceptance of the LGBT community and technology. It’s this era where we’ll place ourselves.

detailscont2.value: Gayborhoods are in transition. Some mark it as the end of “lavender ghettos,” while others mourn the dilution of distinct spaces.

city.text:
Atlanta, one of the nation’s largest black-majority cities, has a storied history of civil rights activism and has long been an oasis for minorities in the South. Many prominent figures from the city, including Coretta Scott King, have drawn a line between the common struggle for blacks and gays. At a 1986 Human Rights Campaign dinner, King affirmed her “solidarity with the gay and lesbian movement.”

Today, Atlanta’s gayborhood in Midtown is permanently marked by a rainbow crosswalk at the intersection of 10th Street and Piedmont Ave. But some residents see the crosswalk as a “headstone” for the area, a physical memorial of the de-gaying of the gayborhood as housing booms, rents rise, and straight couples move in. Katharine, 32, said “The reason minorities live in the city is it’s a safe space. It’s a struggle to be pushed out.”

For now, same-sex male couples are still concentrated in Midtown, but they are noticeably less visible to the east of the city, especially in the lesbian enclaves Kirkwood and of Decatur, colloquially named “Dick hater” (and included in Urban Dictionary since 2004).Although the gayborhood, like any neighborhood, might be in flux, residents still see the need for a dedicated LGBT space. Sara, 34, said “We always say ‘If you go 20 miles out of Atlanta you are in Georgia.’ You can’t leave downtown Atlanta without realizing you’re in the South.”

Massachusetts has led the rest of the country on LGBT issues for decades. In 1989, it became the second state to pass a law prohibiting discrimination against homosexuals in employment, housing, credit and public accommodations. And in 2004, it became the first state in the nation to legalize same-sex marriage. Boston has been the backdrop to it all.

Boston has some distinct gender patterns, with same-sex male households heavily concentrated in the South End and same-sex female households a little farther out in Jamaica Plain. But the city’s traditional LGBT enclaves are undergoing rapid demographic and economic changes that have some residents asking “When Did Boston’s Gay Scene Get So Straight?”

The city that gave us Facebook is also seeing the effects technology can have on its gayborhoods. You don’t have to go to an LGBT bar to meet LGBT people anymore. Boston’s LGBT bars have been closing for the last decade. In 2007, the Boston Globe reported on it; in 2017 it was WBUR is Boston's NPR News Station.

Chicago’s gayborhoods are noticeably split by gender on the maps — they’re even split by name: Boystown (Lakeview) and Girlstown (Andersonville). Today, Boystown is flanked by rainbow pillars and is home to the Pride parade, a dense cluster of gay bars, and the Center on Halsted, an LGBTQ community center that got its start as Horizons Community Services, the Midwest's largest LGBTQ social service agency. But Chicago’s LGBT history doesn’t begin or end with Boystown.

During Prohibition, the South Side’s Bronzeville, a predominantly black neighborhood, was the epicenter of the drag show and cabaret scene. Rising rents pushed the LGBT community from Bronzeville north along Lake Michigan to Boystown where it settled in the 1970s.

Those same forces are at play today. Girlstown, just to the north of Boytowns began to be a lesbian hotspot in the 1990s, centered around the success of local feminist book store Women and Children First. But residents are now mourning the area’s death, as same-sex male couples are continuing their migration north across the Boystown/Girlstown divide.

Houston’s gayborhood is southwest of downtown in the Montrose neighborhood, but the area is currently undergoing a lot of shifts. In 2015, the Pride parade was moved out of Montrose, its home for 36 years, and moved downtown. Malone, 30, who’s first Pride parade was Houston’s last in Montrose, said that at last year’s celebration she marched topless, “Downtown I couldn’t leave the parade route without putting my shirt on. When it was in Montrose, I could just walk in a bar with my nipple pasties on and not get hollered at.”

Montrose is home to a clustering of gay bars between Fairview and Pacific streets and Grant and Hopkins streets. But just a couple streets over new restaurants and sports bars touting craft beer and late-night eats cater to a different clientele. The LGBT community is even trying to reclaim one such bar named the Hay Merchant by calling it the “Gay Merchant.”

As Montrose evolves, Houston’s LGBT community has also started to settle in neighborhoods southeast of downtown like Third Ward and East Downtown and areas to the north like the Heights. Outside the city’s interstate loop is another story. John, 33, said “It’s like the Lion King meme, ‘What’s that dark place outside of Loop 610? We don’t go there.’” Houston’s got a long history of being progressive on LGBT issues: it became the largest city in the US to elect an openly gay mayor with Annise Parker in 2009 and its home to the GLBT Political Caucus, the South’s oldest LGBT civil rights group. But, Houston’s still in Texas, and Texas is still trying to pass “bathroom bill” laws

In the 1990s, sun-soaked Miami gained popularity for a much darker reason. Many HIV positive men made the move to South Beach expecting to die. Miami was a popular destination because of its warm climate and cheap cost of living. As AIDS awareness and medicine improved, this community of gay men made Miami their permanent home.

Miami’s gayborhood is off the mainland on Miami Beach, where there’s a strip of gay bars and the Pride parade runs down Ocean Drive. Miami resident Chris, 33, says the area is home to gay men on all points of the flamboyant and feminine spectrums. Noticeably absent from the LGBT community in Miami? Women. Miami has zero zip codes that register on the female gayborhood index. Miami’s gayborhood, like many big city gayborhoods, has been confronted with rising rents and increasing diversity, but it’s also been exacerbated by a spike in tourism to the south Florida city.

These shifts have pushed some former Miami residents to relocate an hour up the coast to Fort Lauderdale. Miami also competes with Key West and Key Largo as a top LGBT destination.

Philly officially designated an area in Washington Square West from 11th to Broad streets and Pine to Locust as the “Gayborhood” in 2007 (it even appears in Google Maps.), but it’s unofficially been the gay epicenter for decades. It’s home to a dense cluster of bars and anchor institutions like the William Way LGBT Community Center and an outpost of the Mazzoni Center, a healthcare provider for the LGBT community.

A string of incidents in 2016 is forcing Philly’s Gayborhood to confront racism and a lack of intersectionality, but the “City of Brotherly Love” is working to make its LGBT community more inclusive, launching the #MoreColorMorePride campaign and unveiling a new rainbow flag with black and brown stripes added.

Philly resident, Thom, 31, said it’s important to him to have an area where he feels comfortable walking down the street holding his boyfriend’s hand, but he recognizes the Gayborhood might not feel like a safe space for everyone. “If we want people to be invested in these communities we need to create safe spaces for everyone. At the same time, people are doing this without those neighborhoods.” Newer LGBT enclaves are emerging in West Philly (which didn’t appear on our map) and to the north in Germantown and Mount Pleasant where there is a higher concentration of same-sex female couples.

Portland routinely appears on lists of cities with the largest LGBT populations, but it doesn’t have a defined gayborhood. Portland resident David, 40, said “Sometimes I wonder if Portland is the almost the ideal actualized city. There isn’t a central space, but people are welcome and diluted throughout the city.”

Stark Street is still the downtown nightlife destination, but the southwest are known as the “Pink Triangle” or “Vaseline Alley” is a shadow of its former self. Anchor bars began closing one-by-one in the mid 2000s to make way for new development. Economic forces play a part in the area’s transformation, as do wide social acceptance in Portland and technology. David said it wasn’t uncommon to go to bar and see “80 percent of the guys on their phones.”

Portland’s gayborhood index maps show that the entire city could be considered a gayborhood. The most noticeable difference between the two genders is that there is a higher concentration of same-sex male couples downtown in the Pearl District. Men also tend to live northwest of the city, and women to the northeast.

The term “gayborhood” might be synonymous with San Francisco’s Castro, but the neighborhood wasn’t the first LGBT area in the Bay City. Before the 1970s, Polk Gulch was home to the LGBT community. The city’s oldest continously operating LGBT bar, the Gangway, was in the neighborhood, but closed its doors earlier this year.

Today, the Castro is still a stronghold for LGBT nightlife and where there is a high concentration of same-sex male couples. But, the entirety of San Francisco has seen a rapid transformation in the last decade. Rents have skyrocketed, tech companies and wealthy investors have scooped up properties, and many in the LGBT community, especially women and trans people, have moved across the bay to Oakland.

Despite the changes, San Francisco is still billed as the “world’s gay Mecca.” The city has taken steps to preserve some of its LGBT history, designating the nation’s first, transgender culture district and an LGBTQ leather culutre district in the last two years. But, the seismic shifts have some residents saying that the city is too straight, white and corporate.

Dupont, the nation’s capital gayborhood, is draped in rainbow. But, DC area resident Alissa, 27, says that’s true of pretty much all of Washington, “The whole city is gay. It’s hard to go anywhere without seeing a pride flag.” That wide acceptance coupled with economic development and rising rents has decentralized the gayborhood — a trend seen across the nation.

Town Danceboutique, a popular gay dance bar will close on July 1 to make way for an apartment complex. Phase 1, DC’s last lesbian bar, closed in 2016. “I think there’s a juice bar or something there now,” said Alissa. Ed, 54, who moved to DC the first time in 1989 said that technology is also having an effect. “Dupont used to be the place to be, but it’s an app world now. You don’t need a queer friendly bar to meet people.”

Currently a large concentration of same-sex male couples still call Dupont home and are spilling into Shaw, a traditionally black neighborhood. Same-sex female couples are clustered just north in Adams Morgan and Columbia Heights and have spilled across the northeast border into Maryland. Maryland was seen as a cheaper, more liberal choice than the capital’s other neighbor, Virginia. Same-sex couples were able to get married in Maryland a year and 10 months before they were in Virginia.

methodology.value: There’s no comprehensive way to measure gayborhoods or even where LGBT Americans live. This index combines several metrics to create a gayborhoods index to try to get a little bit closer to a complete picture. This index admittedly underweights and undercounts areas with non-binary and minority populations. Data collection needs to catch up with the ways in which we define ourselves.

metrics.dataDesc: Because marriages are tracked at the state level, not federally, the US Treasury Department Office of Tax Analysis linked tax returns with social security numbers to give us the best picture of same-sex marriage in the states after two key Supreme Court rulings on same-sex marriage. In 2013’s Windsor v. United States, the Court invalidated a key provision of the 1996 Defense of Marriage Act and ruled that same-sex couples who were legally married in a start that recognized their marriage should be treated as married for all federal tax purposes. In 2015, the Court ruled in Obergefell v. Hodges that same-sex couples had the right to marry in all states.

The US Census has never asked questions about sexual orientation and gender identity and the department scrapped proposed questions to do so for the 2020 Census. Same-sex unmarried partner households are often used as a proxy for LGBT households, but not without some large caveats. The Census currently reclassifies married same-sex married households as unmarried partners. There is also a known miscoding error that researchers have tried to correct for where different-sex partners incorrectly mark themselves as same-sex partners. A small error in the large population (different sex) creates a large error in the small population (same sex). The gayborhoods index does not perform this adjustment procedure and instead gives less weight to Census data in the index calculations.

Pride parade and march routes often touch historic gayborhoods within cities. The routes have been used to help identify culturally significant areas. In some cities, like Houston, Pride parades and marches have been moved from their traditional homes in gayborhoods to downtown spaces.

Bar locations can help define a commercial corridor for LGBT communities. Businesses tagged “gay bar” within a 10-mile radius were included in the index. It’s important to note that this isn’t an exhaustive measurement and plenty of LGBT spaces were not captured in this data. For example, Diva’s, a popular dance bar within the San Francisco trans community was not tagged as a “gay bar” and therefore not included in the data.

ZIP Codes with fewer than 250 households were not included in this index. ZIP Codes were also limited to within 10 miles of a city’s boundaries. These thresholds were set to lessen any margin of error within small populations and eliminate ZIP Codes where there were no same-sex unmarried partner or same-sex married joint tax filer data.

methodologycont.value: Thank you also to my skilled urban planner wife, Sarah Serpas, who provided valuable insight, pointed me in the right direction and shot me down when I was wrong. We share an apartment in Park Slope, Brooklyn. (Stereotypical, I know).
Get in touch at jan@pudding.cool or on Twitter at jadiehm.
